text_description: Students of a Jesuit school in Cebu perform Vicente Puche, S.J.’s comedia in Latin and Romance to celebrate the arrival of Bishop Pedro de Agurto, the first bishop of Cebu.
Teatro Filipino is built, mounting among others, original Filipino plays in Spanish.
A Modern Filipina, the first Filipino play in English by Jesusa Araullo and Lino Castillejo, is staged.

Jose Carvajal, who is with the commissary of war of the Republica Filipina, and Patrocinio Tagaroma and other artists support the revolutionary government in Malolos as performance artists, mounting productions and recitals.
Ang Pagtabang ni San Miguel, the earliest Waray sarsuwela by Norberto Romualdez is staged at a fiesta in Tolosa, Leyte.

media_caption: A komedya performance in Nueva Ecija, 1985
text_description: Spanish religious establish parishes all over the islands using performances of numerous comedias detailing the lives of saints and the victories of Spanish colonization and evangelization to instruct the natives and attract them to the pueblo. Photo: A komedya performance in Nueva Ecija, 1985. (Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: A 1628 engraving depicting the Martyrs of Nagasaki
text_description: The Japanese execute 26 Catholic religious and laymen who preach Christianity in Nagasaki, Japan. The event becomes the subject for comedias later. Photo: A 1628 engraving depicting the Martyrs of Nagasaki (Engraving by Wolfgang Kilian)
A Jesuit priest writes and presents a comedia, Martirio de Santa Barbara, performed by indios in the local language, as response to the Boholano’s clamor against the new religion.

media_caption: A painting of Jesuit founder St. Ignatius of Loyola
text_description: The datu and principalia of Tinagob in Samar present comedias and entremeses to celebrate the beatification of the Jesuit founder Ignacio de Loyola. (Painting by Peter Paul Rubens)

The bull of Pope Urban VIII on the solemn worship of the Immaculate Conception is celebrated in Manila for 15 days with performances of Comedia de la Hermosura de Rachel and Comedia de los Martires del Japon by the Franciscans; Insigne Comedia de la Concepcion and Comedia de la Venta de Joseph by the Jesuits; and Comedia del Principe de Transilvania by the Agustinians.
Kudarat becomes Corralat in following Spanish comedia texts and performances.
Comedias are performed in Manila to celebrate the beatification of the ‘protomartyrs’ of Japan.
Jesuit college students in Manila perform a re-enactment of Sultan Kudarat’s defeat at the hands of Gov Gen Sebastián Hurtado de Corcuera.

Gran Comedia de la Toma del Pueblo de Corralat y Conquista del Cerro, by Heronimo Perez, SJ, is first performed in Manila. The comedia in Spanish references actual Philippine events, the victory of Spanish forces fighting the Mindanao Moros.
Spanish comedias are translated by celebrated poets in the Tagalog language, as noted by Francisco Colin (1663).
Gaspar de San Agustin mentions an old comedia of San Dionisio Areopaguita, which according to Retana (1909) is written in Tagalog.

To celebrate the birth date of Felipe V, a series of daily performances are held, including Agustin Moreto’s, El Mejor Amigo el Rey, and Juana Ines de la Cruz’s Amor Es Mas Laberinto and Los Empeños de Una Casa and the loas by Gaspar de San Agustin and entremeses.
Gaspar de San Agustin notes in his “Letter on the Filipinos” that there are no feast days celebrated without a comedia performance. San Agustin also notes performances of carillo.
Pedro Murillo Velarde notes the capacity of the natives of the Visayas to create puppets and be puppet-showmen.

Jose de la Cruz (1746 – 1829), aka, Huseng Sisiw, writes and stages the komedya La Guerra Civil de Granada, Hernandez y Galisandra, Reina Encantada o Casamiento por Fuerza, Los Dos Virreyes, Principe Baldovino, Conde Rodrigo de Villas, Doce Pares de Francia, El Amor y La Invidia, Don Gonzalo de Cordoba, Jason y Medea, and Las Traidores de la Patria possibly for Teatro de Tondo.

To celebrate the beatification of the Dominicans Pio V, Diego de Berbaña, and Margarita de Castelo, three comedias, Los Desmayos de Rosa, Las Virtudes de la Rosa, and a comedia on Pio V are performed by students of University of Santo Tomas and Colegio de San Juan de Letran.
Teatro Comico, the first theater in Manila, is built. Four comedias inaugurate the theater to coincide with the days celebrating the coronation of Carlos VI.
Jose Carvajal establishes Teatro Colon in Palomar, the proceeds of which are donated to the cause of the Propaganda Movement, and maintaining La Solidaridad.
A French traveler, Renouard de Saint Croix sees an anonymous vernacular theater production, that delights the viewers so much, in Batac, Ilocos Norte, the first sighting for the Ilocos region.
Teatro de Tondo is established. Domingo Celis, the proprietor, regularly consults Huseng Sisiw on what komedya to show, according to Jose Ma. Rivera (1933).

Poet-priest Anselmo Jorge de Fajardo's kumidya in Kapampangan, Gonzalo de Cordoba / Comedia Heroica de la Conquista de Granada o Sea Vida de Don Gonzalo de Cordoba Llamado el Gran Capitan, is first staged in Bacolor, Pampanga.
Teatro Tagalo de Tondo, aka Teatro de Comedias Tagalas or Coliseo de Tondo, shows komedya, some of which are adapted from korido like Baldovino and Crisalda y Florante.
La Sociedad de Recreo, the first society of theater aficionados, is established.

Magnificent Teatro de Binondo, aka Teatro Viejo de Binondo and Teatro Español, the first Spanish theater in the country, is built. Spanish plays presented in the theater include La Vieja del Candilejo, El Trovador, La Conjuracion de Venecia, La Pata de Cabra, and La Redoma Encantada.
In the Sibacon area of Manila, Teatro Sibacon, is established, with performances of the Tagalog komedya, El Amante Desgraciado o General Perseo.

Political deportees Narciso Escosura, a theater manager, and actress Carlota Coronel further inject professionalism into Spanish theater in the Philippines, and the growing local theater talents who worked with them.

The first professional theater company which arrives in the country, Compañia de Teatro del Vallon of Cadiz, Spain, performs Diego Corrientes, La Flor de la Canela, and El Tio Canilitas at the Teatro de Binondo.
Teatrito de Sibacon operates, with Italian dance teacher based in Madrid Maestro Apiani at the helm, mounting shows like Sargento Marco Barba and La Mariposa.

media_caption: Teatro Circo de Bilibid
article_title: Theater c.1850 Teatro Circo de Bilibid
text_description: Teatro Circo de Bilibid, Manila’s first bullring which became a performance venue for comedias, zarzuelas, vocal solos, and symphonies in the 1870s, is established. (Photo from Lopez Museum Collection)

media_caption: Portrait of Fedor Jagor, 1886
text_description: Feodor Jagor (in photo) watches a comedia in Spanish in Nabua, Albay. (Portrait by Christian Wilhelm Allers)

Guillermo Manlangit produces his Bikol komedya Comedia Famosa de Don Alejandre y Don Luis de Aragon y Moscobia during the town fiesta of Bato, Catanduanes, the earliest known komedya in the local Bikol language.
Jose Rizal (1861 - 1896) recalls witnessing scenes of the temptation of Christ and the burial of the dead Christ in Laguna homes.
Sociedad del Teatro Infantil de Dulumbayan, the first theater society with an indigenous membership, is established.

The Suez Canal in Egypt opens, shortening travel time from the Philippines to Spain. Wealthy Filipinos travel to Europe to study. Liberal ideas, influenced by the Enlightenment, reach the colony. This event will subsequently bring more Spanish and Italian performing groups doing operas and zarzuelas in the Philippines.

media_caption: El barberillo de Lavapiés: zarzuela en tres actos y en verso, 1874
text_description: Spanish zarzuelas, Jugar con Fuego and El Barberillo de Lavapiés (in photo) are presented by Dario Cespedes’ troupe, the first Spanish zarzuelas to be shown in the Philippines. (Photo from Biblioteca Digital de Madrid)
Teatro de Variedades is established, with French and Spanish companies mounting productions, among others.

media_caption: El Consejo de los Dioses, a play written in Spanish by José Rizal first published in 1880, adapted by Lope Blas Hucapte in 1918
text_description: · Jose Rizal writes an allegorical play, El Consejo de los Dioses, winning a prize in a contest sponsored by Liceo Artistico Literario de Manila.

Alejandro Cubero and actress Elisea Raguer arrive from Spain. Cubero organizes the Compañia de Zarzuela Cubero, and with base at Teatro Filipino trains the first generation of Filipino actors in the Spanish zarzuelas. For this, he is called “the Father of Spanish Theater in the Philippines”.

media_caption: Script Cover of Junto al Pasig
text_description: Jose Rizal’s Junto Al Pasig is staged at the Salon de Actos at the Ateneo de Manila. The play obliquely questions Spanish colonialism. Photo: Script Cover of Junto al Pasig (CCP Collection)
Francisco de P. Entrala’s sainete Cuadros Filipinos, the first known play set in Manila with Manileño characters, is staged in Teatro Filipino.

A komediya in Ilocano from an anonymous writer, Gonzalo de Cordova o la Conquista de Granada por los Reyes Catolicos de España, is written and mounted, and survives up to the years after the World War II in the Ilocos region.
Teatro Junquera, believed to be the most important theater in Cebu City in the late 19th and early 20th century, is inaugurated.
Felix B. Millan from Calasiao, Pangasinan writes an Ilocano komedya, Vida de Palmarin de Oliva. The manuscript turns up after the WWII in Tayum, Abra.
Budhing Nagpahamak, considered as the first Tagalog sarsuwela by an anonymous Bulacan playwright, with music by Isidro Roxas, is performed.

Praxedes Julia Fernandez, Venancia Suzara, and Patrocinio Tagaroma, leading zarzuela actresses of the time, all trained by Alejandro Cubero, bond together to form the FERSUTA company, performing for Manila audiences and touring shows in the provinces.
Before the revolution, Tagalog theaters like Teatro Infantil de Dulumbayan, Teatro Tagalo de Tanduay, Teatro Guiñol, Teatro Infantil de Aguila, and Teatro Infantil Tagalo, are established.
Compañia Zarzuela de la Torre is founded by Hugo de la Torre in Legaspi, Albay mounting Spanish language plays.
Mga Santong Tao by Tomas Remigio exemplifies the drama comico, attacking hypocrisy of church people.

media_caption: Sinakulo in Baliuag, Bulacan, 2013
text_description: The sinakulo as a theater form flourishes during the first decade of the 20th century as stated by Nicanor G. Tiongson (1975). Arthur S. Riggs (1905) mentions sinakulo productions which he calls “passion play.” Photo: Sinakulo in Baliuag, Bulacan, 2013 (Ramon F. Velasquez)
Say Liman Ag Naketket, Pampinsioan, considered the first Pangasinan sarsuwela, written by Catalino Palisoc, with music by Juan Aquino, is first staged in Lingayen, Pangasinan.
The vaudeville group, the Lilliputians, performs in the Philippines.
Teatro Zorrilla presents Novelty in Manila, an American production featuring various acts like comedy skits, acrobatics, contortionists’ display, singing and dancing.

media_caption: Playbill of R.I.P. and Ang Kalupi
text_description: R.I.P., a controversial play by Severino Reyes, is premiered along with Reyes’s Ang Kalupi, with music by Fulgencio Tolentino. Both are performed by Compañia Lirico-Dramatica Tagala de Gatchalian e Ilagan at the Teatro Libertad. Photo: Playbill of R.I.P. and Ang Kalupi (CCP Collection)

media_caption: Ex-Rep. Vicente Sotto
text_description: The first performance of Elena at the Teatro Junquera, Cebu’s first and most important theater, establishes the reputation of Vicente Sotto (in photo) in Cebuano theater. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Walang Sugat, 2012
text_description: Severino Reyes's Walang Sugat is staged at the Teatro Libertad in Manila by Gran Compañia de la Zarzuela Tagala, the leading sarsuwela troupe in the country in the first two decades of the 20th century founded by Reyes. Photo: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Walang Sugat, 2012 (Jory Rivera)
Tomas Remigio’s drama simboliko Malaya, written in 1898 in Spain, is first staged by Dulaang Luzon in Santa Cruz.

media_caption: Pedro Paterno
text_description: La Alianza Sonada (Dreamed Alliance), an opera by Pedro Paterno (in photo) is performed with music by Ladislao Bonus at the Teatro Zorrilla. (Photo from CCP)

The performance of Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas by Aurelio Tolentino at the Teatro Libertad is halted. Tolentino, who also played Taga-Ilog, is arrested, charged, and found guilty of sedition. During trial, he is defended by Manuel L. Quezon. He is imprisoned, one of his nine, for two years and is fined with $2,000.
Ang Capitan, the first Ilonggo sarsuwela, written by Valente Cristobal, with music by Juan Paterno, is first staged at Teatro Filipino in Iloilo.

Hindi Aco Patay, a drama-simboliko by Juan Matapang Cruz is first performed, but its May 10 performance at the Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon is banned mid-performance. The troupe, including his wife, is arrested and imprisoned.
An anonymous drama-simboliko piece, Ang Kalayaan Hindi Natupad, is closed in Obando, Bulacan.
A staging of Mariano Martinez’s Pulong Pinaglahuan at the Teatro Navotas is raided in Navotas, Rizal. Martinez and 20 performers are arrested.
Maximino de los Reyes is arrested for the staging of his own Dahas ng Pilak at the Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon, Rizal. De los Reyes, along with the manager and 11 actors, are arrested.
In the performance of Ang Katipunan by Gabriel Beato Francisco in Laoag, Ilocos Norte, the troupe, and the entire audience are arrested.
Asisclo Jimenez writes and later mounts the Sorsogon Bikolano sarswela Pagkamoot sa Banuang Tinoboan. It is considered among the best of Bikol sarswela.
First known Ilocano sarsuwela Codigo Municipal and Maysa Nga Candidato by Mena Pecson Crisologo are mounted on the occasion of the Vigan, Ilocos Sur town fiesta.
The sarsuwela Nating, with music by Teodoro Gallego, the first full-length and most famous work by Valente Cristobal, is first performed at the Teatro F. Malhabour in Iloilo City.

media_caption: Wenceslao E. Retana, circa 1901
text_description: Noticias Historico-Bibliograficas de el Teatro en Filipinas desde sus Origenes hasta 1898, authored by Wenceslao E. Retana (in photo), is published by Libreria General de Victoriano Suarez in Madrid. It is the most reliable and well-researched source book on Philippine theater in its time. (Photo by Manuel Alviach, Nuevo Mundo)
Compania Zarzuela de Camalig is organized by Anacleto Solano in Camalig, Albay; it presents Spanish plays until 1912.
Compania Zarzuela Bicolana is organized by Justino Nuyda in Camalig, Albay after the demise of the hispanophone Compania Zarzuela de Camalig.
Sabas Armenta stages in Albay Comedia ni Hadeng Grimaldo sa Reinong Irlanda, a Bikol komedya deviating from conventions and exploring social and political concerns.
The bodabil (vaudeville), a potpourri of American songs and dances, and comedy skits becomes popular in the Philippines.
Borromeo Lou stages the first bodabil show at the Olympic Stadium in Manila.
Fr. Henry Lee Irwin mounts Julius Caesar in English, the first production of the Ateneo Players’ Guild.

Konde Urbano, penned by Fortunato Esorena and directed by Juan Valenzuela Sr, is the inaugural production of Comedia de Baler or Tropang Komedya ng Baler, a komedya group from Barangay Buhangin, Baler, Aurora.

Barbaro Paat (b. 1914) continues to mount Iloko sarsuwela all over the Ilocos region and beyond in Pangasinan, Nueva Vizcaya, Nueva Ecija, Isabela and Cagayan, where Ilocanos have migrated. Paat’s group performs sarsuwela even after martial law.

From 1938 to 1972, the Institute of National Language conducts and publishes lectures in Filipino on Philippine arts and culture. Jose Ma. Rivera, Severino Reyes, and Julian Cruz Balmaceda are among the presentors on Philippine theater.

The Institute of National Language publishes Severino Reyes’s Dulang Tagalog, one of the earliest historical accounts of the development of Philippine theater forms, particularly, the moro-moro and sarsuwela.
Three one-act plays, Alice Gerstenberg’s The Pot Boiler, John Farrar’s Nerves, and Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s Women Are Extraordinary inaugurate Barangay Theater Guild at the Manila Grand Opera House.
Call Me Mike, a comedy in three acts by Reach and Taggart, is staged at the Metropolitan Theater as the Far Eastern University Theater Guild’s first production.
With the cessation of filmmaking, Filipinos throng the theaters to watch the stage show which expands pre-war bodabil with the addition of a complete play at the end.

media_caption: Popular bald pair, the late Pugo (right) and Tugo incurred Nippon displeasure with their stage dig at the enemy
media_credit: Photo from The Sunday Times Magazine, Presidential Museum and Library
text_description: Pugo and Tugo(in photo), and other bodabil artists maintain a nationalist stance, and boost the morale of a people suffering under Japanese rule. (Photo from The Sunday Times Magazine, Presidential Museum and Library)

article_title: Theater 1945 Up Limit Pati an Gugma
text_description: Up Limit Pati an Gugma, a drama nga kinantahan (drama with occasional songs and music) by Iluminado Lucente, criticizes Leyteños’ fondness for anything American. It is first staged during the fiesta of Tacloban City.

The first winners of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature prizes for the one-act play category include Dionisio S. Salazar, Lazaro R. Banag Jr, and Deogracias D. Tigno, in the Filipino division; and Alberto S. Florentino, Fidel Sicam, and Paulina Bautista, in the English division.

media_caption: Daisy Avellana, center, and Dolly Benavidez as Candida and Paula, respectively, in the original production of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, Aurora Gardens, Intramuros, Manila, 1955
article_title: Theater 1955 A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino play
text_description: A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, by Nick Joaquin by Nick Joaquin, conceded by critics to be the most important Filipino play in English, is first staged by the Barangay Theater Guild at the Aurora Gardens in Intramuros, Manila. Daisy H. Avellana (left) and Dolly Buenavides originate the roles of Candida and Paula, respectively. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Bb. Julie, Strindberg’s play in Filipino, directed by Rolando S. Tinio for the inaugural production of Repertory Philippines, with Ella Luansing as Julie and Antonio Amador as Jean, 1967
media_credit: Photo from Antonio L. Tinio, The Rolando S. Tinio Blog
text_description: Bb. Julie, Rolando Tinio's Filipino translation of August Strindberg's Miss Julie, is mounted as Repertory Philippines’ inaugural production, starring Ella Luansing and Antonio Amador. (Photo from Antonio L. Tinio, The Rolando S. Tinio Blog)

The first winners of CCP Playwriting Contest include Angel R. Makiling, Dionisio Salazar, and Leonardo V. Ilagan, in the Filipino division; and Elsa M. Coscolluela, Jose M. Hernandez, and Virginia Moreno, in the English division.

article_title: Theater 1970 Ang Kalbaryo ni Juan Holy Week
text_description: Holy Week: In Tanghalang Bayan ’s Ang Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz, Christ is represented as the Filipino Juan whipped by truncheon-wielding fascists. The procession of the Tondo-based artists led by Levy Balgos de la Cruz starts at Pritil Street passes through Juan Luna, and ends at Plaza Moriones.
Kolambugan Dance Theatre presents its initial production, Rajah Indarapatra, written by Rodulfo Galenzoga, an adaptation of the Omaacan episode in the Muslim epic of the same name.
Virginia Moreno’s The Onyx Wolf, under the direction of Rolando Tinio inaugurates the Little Theater (later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

article_title: Theater 1971 Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa
text_description: Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa, written by Bonifacio Ilagan and directed by Leo Rimando, is staged by Panday Sining.
Hukumang Bayan is staged by Tanghalang Bayan in UNOS II at the Abelardo Hall.
Gintong Silahis stages Alay Kay Ka Amado during the National Language Week at the UP Abelardo Hall, followed by its biggest production, Barikada.
The Pest of Badway is staged at the Cultural Center of the Philippines driveway by activists groups, led by Behn Cervantes and Leo Rimando.

media_caption: Cecile Guidote-Alvarez as Ramon Magsaysay Awardee, 1972
article_title: Theater 1972 Ramon Magsaysay Award Cecile Guidote-Alvarez
text_description: Cecile Guidote-Alvarez receives the Ramon Magsaysay award. (Photo from Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)

Bonifacio Ilagan’s Welga! Welga!, under the direction of Leo Rimando, is first staged, marking the ascendancy of activist cultural groups during the peak of the student and activist movement, months before the declaration of martial law.
Obon Di Malayad, Inc. stages Ina, a collaborative project of members of the community of Lubon, Mountain Province.

media_caption: Dulaang Babaylan’s La India Elegante y El Negrito Amante, featuring Jay Valencia, seated, and Soxie Topacio, right, Philamlife Auditorium, Manila, 1973
text_description: Babaylan Theater Group, which stands for the revival and revitalization of Philippine traditional plays, mounts Ay Puso!, consisting of Francisco Baltazar’s La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante (in photo), Cirio H. Panganiban’s Veronidia, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sino Ba Kayo? (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

Sinakulo I and II, a traditional and modern sinakulo, are staged by Babaylan Theater Group during the Lenten season at the Luneta open-air auditorium, a breakthrough performance regrouping activist theater artists and cultural workers, just a few months after declaration of martial law.

The first winners of the PAVT are Reuel Molina Aguila, Manny D. Pambid, Nonilon Queaño, Mauro Avena, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, Rosauro dela Cruz, Edwin Daiwey, Reynaldo Duque, Mol Fernando, Victor Francisco, Carlos Gutierrez, and Angelito Tiongson.
Rodulfo Galenzoga’s Maranatha, is staged by the Kolambugan Dance Theater ensemble in Kolambugan, Lanao del Norte, and is later toured.

media_caption: A performance of Ang Mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz in Malolos, Bulacan, 1989
text_description: Ang Mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz, a poem by Jose F. Lacaba, becomes the title and text for the first tula-dula as first performed and innovated by the UP Repertory Company at the Mater Dei Auditorium of St. Joseph’s College in Quezon City. Photo: A performance of Ang Mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz in Malolos, Bulacan, 1989 (CCP Collection)
In Dis Korner by Reuel Molina Aguila, under the direction of Anton Juan Jr, is first staged by Dulaang UP in UP Diliman.

RPN (Repleksyon ng Pangangailangan ng Nakararami) gets popularized and accepted particularly by theater artists and cultural workers as a basic principle in literary and theater production, permeating the curriculum, particularly the outreach and summer workshops of PETA.
Buhay Batilyo, Hindi Kami Susuko, written by Manny Pambid, on the plight of fishport dock workers, is staged at the Luneta Open Air Theater by members of a community theater in Quezon City.

media_caption: Teatro Pilipino’s Ang Abaniko with stage design by National Artist for Theater Design Salvador F. Bernal, 1975
media_credit: Photo from Antonio L. Tonio, The Rolando S. Tinio Blog
text_description: Carlo Goldoni’s Ang Abaniko inaugurates Teatro Pilipino at the Little Theater of the CCP, translation and direction by founder Rolando Tinio. Also included in the inaugural year are Anton Chekhov’s Tiyo Vanya; and Alexei Arbuzov’s Kawawang Marat. (Photo from Antonio L. Tonio, The Rolando S. Tinio Blog)

article_title: Theater 1977 Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan
text_description: Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan by Bonifacio Ilagan, under Tony Espejo’s direction, inaugurates CCP’s Bulwagang Gantimpala, now Tanghalang Huseng Batute.

media_caption: Poster of Teatro Tomasino's inaugural play Ang Awit na Hindi Matapos-tapos, 1978
article_title: Theater 1977 Ang Awit na Hindi Matapos-tapos
text_description: Ang Awit na Hindi Matapos-tapos by Orlando Nadres, under the direction of Maryo J. de los Reyes, is the inaugural production of Teatro Tomasino. (Photo from Teatro Tomasino)

Ang Pagbabalik ng Musikero, written by Nonilon Queaño and directed by Tony Mabesa, is staged by the University of the Philippines College Baguio (UPCB) Summer Theater Arts Workshop at the UPCB Auditorium in Baguio City.
Ay! Ay! Kalayaan, co-produced with UP Bigkis Sining and Tulisanes, is Teatro Umalohokan’s inaugural production.
Ito ba ang Iligan? by Steven Patrick Fernandez is staged by the Integrated Performing Arts Guild (IPAG).

media_caption: PETA’s Juan Tamban, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1987
text_description: A major play by Malou Leviste Jacob, Juan Tamban, is first staged, under the direction of Joel Lamangan, at Fort Santiago, Manila. A thorough documentation of the process and the various aspects of this PETA commissioned play is found in Juan Tamban, edited by Apolonio B. Chua (1984). (Photo from PETA Library and Archives)

Bienvenido Noriega's Ramona Reyes ng Forbes Park and a translation of an Emil Braginsky and Eldar Ryanzanoz play entitled Naibigan Mo Sana ang Sauna is staged by Tanghalang Ateneo for its first season.
From a simple caroling group, Tambisan sa Sining, Inc. is formalized to spearhead cultural work for Kilusang Mayo-Uno.

article_title: Theater 1980 Ibon Man May Layang Lumipad
text_description: Ibon Man May Layang Lumipad is mounted as Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna’s (PASILAG) initial offering.
Konsyerto sa Kahaponon is staged by Sining Malay Ensemble, the performing arm of Kulturang Atin Foundation, Inc. (KAFI).
Dahong Palay, a screenplay by Marina Feleo-Gonzales, is adapted for the stage and directed by Chris Millado for UP Tropang Bodabil, at the UP Diliman as part of the UP Diamond Jubilee celebration.

Seventeen plays from Metro Manila and the different regions are staged at the First MAKIISA Festival, among them: Dulaang Palanyag’s Pabrika, Barasoain Kalinangan’s Masaker, Negros Theater League’s Sakada, and Lanao Educational Arts for Development’s Usa Pa Ka Pakigbisog.

article_title: Theater 1984 Levy Balgos de la Cruz plays
text_description: Ang Pipi sa Kaingin and Lakay Igolot by Levy Balgos de la Cruz, both tackling the problems of cultural communities and militarization, are performed by members of the New Peoples Army in the Cordilleras.
Chris Millado’s Ang Nazarena, directed by Joi Barrios, is mounted as part of trilogy Kutsilyo, Pamaypay, at Yantok, at the Faculty Center Theater, University of the Philippines.
Socially-oriented plays are presenterd at the second Makiisa Festival of People’s Culture.

media_caption: Lino Brocka as Ramon Magsaysay Awardee, 1985
article_title: Theater 1985 Ramon Magsaysay Award Lino Brocka
text_description: Lino Brocka receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award. (Photo from Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)
The tula-dula Bulawan by Arnel Mardoquio, Tony Apat, and Mario Castillo, is first staged by Mindanao Council for People’s Culture.

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Dalagang Bukid, featuring Noemi Manikan-Gomez, center, CCP, Manila, 1987
text_description: Dalagang Bukid, the famous sarsuwela by Leon Ignacio and Hermogenes Ilagan, is mounted by Tanghalang Pilipino as its inaugural production, with Nonon Padilla as director. The production is also a tribute to newly proclaimed National Artist, Atang de la Rama, who starred in the original production. (Photo from Tanghalang Pilipino)

media_caption: Poster for Chris Millado's Desaparecidos, as seen in the playbill of CCP's Sining Para sa Kalayaan, 1987
text_description: Dulaang UP mounts Chris Millado’s Desaparecidos, direction by Jorge Ledesma, on salvaging and disappearance during the Marcos regime. Photo: Poster for Chris Millado's Desaparecidos, as seen in the playbill of CCP's Sining Para sa Kalayaan, 1987 (CCP Collection)

Bang-bang Alu, an Enrico C. Santos monologue, is first produced along with two other set pieces, namely Reuel Molina Aguila’s Alimuom and Chris Millado’s Babaing Itawis, comprising a trilogy for the Third World Theater Company in its first season.

article_title: Theater 1988 A Long Day's Journey into Night
text_description: Eugene O’Neill’s A Long Day’s Journey into Night is staged at the Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center, leading to the establishment of Dramatis Personae Foundation in 1989, with founders Lito Casaje and Bienvenido M. Noriega Jr.

article_title: Theater 1989 Gawad CCP Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero
text_description: Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero for Theater.

media_caption: Lea Salonga as Kim in the West End musical Miss Saigon, 1989
text_description: Filipino talents get international exposure and recognition as Lea Salonga (in photo), Monique Wilson, and other Filipino theater artists audition and win plum roles in the West End musical Miss Saigon in London. This leads to Salonga winning the Best Actress in a Musical award in the 1991 Tony Awards.

Tanghalang Silangan (eventually Teatro Pabrika) stages Eksena ng Kulungan, a playlet on prison as metaphor for victims, activists and innocents at Our Lady of Angels Seminary, Novaliches, Quezon City.
Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) for Theater.

article_title: Theater 1991 Ang Maikling BUhay ng Apoy
text_description: A mythic Palawan play, Ang Maikling Buhay ng Apoy by Auraeus Solito is first staged by the UP Tropa in the wooded area beside the Faculty Center, UP Diliman.
Ateneo Blue Repertory stages Pippin as its initial offering. Other western Broadway musicals such as The Wiz, Godspell, and The Fantasticks follow.
CCP launches the Unang Tagpo: National Theater Festival.
Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to Onofre Pagsanghan for Theater and the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.
Peter Brook’s Carmen is staged by Actor’s Actors Inc’s as its initial offering.
Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is awarded to Rolando S. Tinio for Theater and to Samahang Nazareno for Folk Theater.
Suntok sa Buwan, a play that depicts environmental problems, launches Arts Research and Training institute in Southern Luzon or ARTIST Inc’s seasons of plays.
Ti Nagbati, a street play, is mounted by Kalingaw, Ang Teatro Hiligaynon as its initial production.
David Mamet’s Oleanna, which tackles the issue of sexual abuse boldly, is mounted as New Voice Company’s initial offering.

media_caption: Simeon A. Ola performed at the 2nd National Theater Festival, 1996
text_description: Simeon A. Ola by Bernardo Aguay, Jazmin B. Llana, and July Mendoza, a drama on the life of a Bikol revolutionary, is first staged at the UP Los Baños by the Kaboronyogan Cultural Network. Photo: Simeon A. Ola performed at the 2nd National Theater Festival, 1996 (CCP Collection)

Batubayani, a play on Rizal, is staged by the Ateneo Children’s Theater as part of a trilogy to celebrate the centennial of the Philippine Revolution. This is followed by Gregorio del Pilar: Ang Batang Heneral, 1997, and Mga Bata ng Himagsikan, 1998.
The Ikalawang Tagpo: National Theater Festival is held at the CCP.

media_caption: Sining Kambayoka Ensemble, Gawad CCP Para Sa Sining Pantanghalan
text_description: The Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio for Theater, Teodoro L. Hilado for Technical Theater, and Sining Kambayoka (in photo) and Nicanor G. Tiongson for Cultural Work. (Photo from CCP)
Andres Bonifacio: Anak ng Bayan is staged as Tanghalang Saint Louis University’s initial theater offering.

Japanese lights designer Naomi “Shoko” Matsumoto leads the establishment of the Sinag Arts Foundation, and eventually the Sinag Arts Studio to serve as a training center for Filipinos on technical theater.
Basura by Alphonsus Tesoro is staged as the initial production of Dagway Sigmahanon Incorporated, a theater group based in Sigma, Capiz.

media_caption: Tales from Mindanao, considered the Philippines’ most-traveled repertory production, is a dance-music series about Mindanao and its people.
text_description: Tales from Mindanao, a play mounted by the Integrated Performing Arts Guild (IPAG), receives the grand prize in the Concourse de Chanson Internationaux. (Photo from IPAG)
Lupad is mounted by The Performance Laboratory Incorporated (PerfLab) as its initial production.
Usa ka Damgo, a play on the Mindanaoan people’s search for peace, is staged by Artists’ Quarter.
Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to Cecile Guidote Alvarez for Theater, Rene O. Villanueva for Literature, the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. and Doreen G. Fernandez for cultural work.
The Ikatlong Tagpo: National Theater Festival is held.

Alice Tan Gonzales’s adaptation of Magdalena Jalandoni’s novel Juanita Cruz marks an aesthetic development in Panay or West Visayas theater production, as film and film techniques are integrated into a performance.
Butil ng Liwanag is mounted by Collective Arts of Students and Thespians (CAST), a cultural organization based in the University of Makati.
UP sponsors Komedya Fiesta 2008 featuring active komedya groups of the country and a conference. Dulaang UP mounts Orosman at Zafira for the occasion.
Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to Felix Monino S. Duque for Theater and Malou L. Jacob for Literature.

media_caption: Zeneida Amador, Gawad CCP Para Sa Sining sa Teatro
text_description: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is awarded to Zeneida Amador for Theater. (Photo from CCP)
Games People Play by Glenn Sevilla Mas, first staged as a dramatic reading by Tanghalang Pilipino for Virgin Labfest, has its first full staging as Ed Lacson’s thesis production at the UP Diliman.
Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is awarded to Antonio O. Mabesa for Theater.
